snippet: At a meeting of the University of California Board of Regents here this week, Ward Connerly, a businessman from Sacramento, made a plea to his 18 co-Regents to consider the possibility that the affirmative action policies pursued in California ove...
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the University of California Board of Regents here this week, Ward Connerly, a businessman from Sacramento, made a plea to his 18 co-Regents to consider the possibility that the affirmative action policies pursued in California over the last quarter century might be "unfair" and "inequitable." "What we are doing is inequitable to certain people, and I want us as a university to begin thinking about what we are doing and to begin to change," Mr. Connerly, who is black, told the board that governs the vast California university system, with its nine campuses, its 162,000 students and $10 billion annual budget.

headline.main: Moves Under Way in California to Overturn Higher Education's Affirmative Action Policy
